titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Nelson W. Aldrich papers FA068

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-12-11 00:05:19 -0500.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Nelson W. Aldrich papers are arranged in 10 series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: 1841, November 6: Born in Foster, Rhode Island
1865: Became junior partner in Rhode Island wholesale grocery firm
1869-1875: Member of Providence Common Council; president, 1872-1873
1875-1877: Member of State House of Representatives; Speaker of the House, 1876-1877
1879-1881: Member of U.S. House of Representatives
1915, April 16: Died in New York, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Nelson W. Aldrich (1841-1915), statesman, financier, and businessman, span the years 1777 to 1930, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the years 1879 to 1915. The collection is composed primarily of correspondence, printed matter, and material relating to tariff legislation and the National Monetary Commission, supplemented by diaries, notebooks, speeches, research notes, serials, financial papers, and miscellaneous items.

The collection focuses on Aldrich's 30 years of service as a U.S. Senator from Rhode Island, 1881 to 1911. During this lengthy career, Aldrich rose from the relatively obscure position of junior Senator from a small state to become one of the most influential members of the Senate by the close of the nineteenth century. His elevation to the chairmanship of the powerful Senate Finance Committee in 1899 underscored his national prominence, a fact recognized by successive Presidents until his voluntary retirement in 1911. Aldrich's primary concern as a senator centered on national economic and fiscal policy, particularly tariff and monetary policy. By personal business experience, ideological considerations, and the realities of Rhode Island politics, Aldrich normally exerted his influence on behalf of the protective tariff rates and conservative monetary policies favored by powerful northeastern business interests.

The Aldrich papers reflect the Senator's deep involvement with national economic policy. Tariff legislation is a recurring theme throughout the correspondence series, particularly during the years of major tariff revision in 1890, 1897, and 1909. The correspondence, mainly incoming mail from businessmen representing a wide range of economic interests, reveals the depth of feeling generated by the prospect of tariff revision and the importance of the issue during these years. The letters also provide an insight into American business practices and the economic views of a large segment of the American business community during this era of rapid industrial expansion. Aldrich's personal attention to the details of rate revision is clearly revealed in the tariff file, while his speeches help document his general attitude toward tariff duties as a source of protection for American industry from foreign competition.

Aldrich gave considerable attention during his last years in office to the problems of U.S. monetary policy. Following the Panic of 1907, with its accompanying rash of bank failures, he cosponsored the Aldrich-Vreeland Act of 1908, providing for the establishment of a National Monetary Commission to study banking and currency operations at home and abroad and to suggest changes in American practices.

The National Monetary Commission's correspondence for the years 1908-1912 thoroughly documents its activities and Aldrich's role as chairman. Much of the Commission's correspondence was with bankers, public officials, financial experts, and academicians employed to prepare special studies, translate documents, and collect statistics on financial operations and monetary systems in foreign nations as well as in the United States. Aldrich and other members of the Commission visited England, France, and Germany to consult with experts and collect data, and specialists representing the Commission made similar visits to other nations and reported their findings. Hearings were held in selected American cities to solicit opinions from bankers and other interested parties, while numerous individuals sent unsolicited opinions and plans directly to the Commission. Most of the letters were sent and received by Abram Piatt Andrew, special assistant to the Commission, Arthur B. Shelton, secretary to the Commission, and staff members Charles E. Alden, J. Williar Sheetz, and William A. Slade.

Aldrich's personal views are reflected in occasional correspondence, speeches delivered to promote monetary reform, and in the final report of the Commission--soon labeled the "Aldrich Plan." The Commission's correspondence is also a rich source of information for students of American financial institutions of the early twentieth century and expounds the views of a small but influential segment of the financial community at this time. The National Monetary Commission file contains most of its publications as well as a sampling of the collected data and related material.

Soon after the death of Senator Henry B. Anthony in 1884, Aldrich assumed Anthony's former position as the most powerful figure in Rhode Island politics. Letters from numerous state political figures, particularly Henry B. Gardner and Charles R. Brayton, kept the busy Senator abreast of local affairs and at the same time reveal his influence in state political circles. The numerous requests for favors, advice, and patronage further attest to his influence.

Aldrich's personal affairs and family relations form a relatively small portion of the collection. A short series of letters written to his future wife in 1865-1866 offers a glimpse into his personal relations and plans at this time. Another small group of letters written to Mrs. Aldrich during his first trip abroad in 1872-1873 adds to our knowledge of his family relations and reveals his initial impressions of European society and culture. Scattered letters in the correspondence series and the financial papers allow a brief insight into his extensive financial ventures, particularly his investments in the rubber industry.

Aldrich's principal correspondents include William B. Allison, Henry B. Anthony, Jonathan Bourne, Jr., Charles R. Brayton, Jonathan Chace, William E. Chandler, Charles A. Conant, Henry P. Davison, Eugene Hale, Philander C. Knox, Charles Warren Lippitt, Stephen B. Luce, Orville H. Platt, Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, Henry M. Teller, Paul M. Warburg, and George Peabody Wetmore.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center purchased a microfilm copy of a large portion of the Nelson W. Aldrich papers, the originals of which are in the custody of the Manuscript Division of the Library of Congress.

The papers of Nelson Wilmarth Aldrich were presented to the Library of Congress in four installments. The first installment was received in 1944 from Aldrich's children, Winthrop W. Aldrich and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; and Mr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr., made two additions to the collection in 1955 and 1956 from the papers of his late wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. The last installment was presented to the Library in 1970 by the Seminary of Our Lady of Providence, Rhode Island.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of U.S. copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The original records are held by the Manuscript Division of the Library of Congress and are not available at the RAC. User copies of the microfilm are available for scholarly access.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains diaries and social engagement books of Abby C. Aldrich, bound and unbound shorthand letters and notes of Nelson W. Aldrich, a Civil War company roll book, a fraternal lodge address book, minutes of the Senate Finance Committee for Dec. 1863 to June 1864, and a journal relating to the Hepburn Act of 1906.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Container 1, available from the Manuscripts Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C. 20540

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abby C. Aldrich diaries (2), Jan. 1904 and Jan.-May 1912 Abby C. Aldrich engagement books (5), 1905-10 Hepburn Act journal, no author, 1927 Civil War roll book, 1863 Fraternal lodge address book, no date Senate Finance Committee minutes, Dec. 1863-June 1864 Bound shorthand letters, ca. Dec. 1882-Jan. 1884 Bound shorthand notes, no date Unbound shorthand letters, ca. 1882-1909 and undated

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters received and occasional letters sent by Nelson W. Aldrich, and letters sent and received by staff members of the National Monetary Commission.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains publications of the National Monetary Commission and miscellaneous draft reports, proceedings, statements, statistics, and papers relating to the National Monetary Commission.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: This series is not available at the Rockefeller Archive Center. It has been microfilmed and may be available to researchers through a local public or university library, or through the Library of Congress's Manuscripts Division.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by type of material and chronologically therein.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains research notes collected by Jeannette P. Nichols and Nathaniel W. Stephenson for the latter's biography, "Nelson W. Aldrich, a Leader in American Politics" (1930), supplemented by one folder of related correspondence and a few miscellaneous items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains checkbooks, checks, statements, bills, receipts, vouchers, occasional correspondence, and miscellaneous items relating to both Nelson W. Aldrich's personal financial affairs and the financial transactions of the National Monetary Commission.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically and by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is grouped by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains bound facsimile letters, biographical information, material relating to Aldrich's rubber investments, speeches, articles, memoranda, proceedings, briefs, cases, contracts, reports, requests for supplies, cards, tickets, three scrapbooks of clippings relating primarily to tariff and banking matters, acknowledgments, invitations, loose clippings, photographs, and miscellaneous items.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Reels 70-73 of this series are not available at the Rockefeller Archive Center. Researchers should consult a local public or university library for this portion of the microfilm edition, or the Library of Congress's Manuscripts Division.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
